KB Retrieval SG Retrieval
Supervised 59.10 60.00
unsupervised 17.5 27.12
references: The accuracy of our retrieval module for both scene-graph and knowledge base is shown in Table 1. While top-1 retrieval accuracy for both SG and KB is around 60%percent6060\%, top-100 accuracy for both models is almost 100%percent100100\%. We can see that top-1 accuracy without training (using cosine similarity of text embedding) is less than half of the accuracy for the supervised retrieval.

To have a more realistic setting, we made efforts to provide results with approximated scene graphs as well. Given an image I, we used Faster-RCNN Ren et al. (2015) to identify a set of objects O={oi}i=1K,(K=36)𝑂subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑜𝑖𝐾𝑖1𝐾36O=\{o_{i}\}^{K}_{i=1},(K=36), where each object oisubscript𝑜𝑖o_{i} is associated with a visual feature vector vi∈Rdv,(dv=2048)subscript𝑣𝑖superscript𝑅subscript𝑑𝑣subscript𝑑𝑣2048v_{i}\in R^{d_{v}},(d_{v}=2048), and a corresponding label. The final scene graph is shown as GV=(VV,EV)subscript𝐺𝑉superscript𝑉𝑉superscript𝐸𝑉G_{V}=(V^{V},E^{V}) over objects O𝑂O, where VV=viVi=1Ksuperscript𝑉𝑉subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑉𝑖𝐾𝑖1V^{V}={v^{V}_{i}}^{K}_{i=1} is the node set and each node viVsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑉𝑖v^{V}_{i} corresponds to a detected object oisubscript𝑜𝑖o_{i}. We have trained our scene graph generation method using the training data introduced in Xu et al. (2017) (VG150). VG150 includes the most frequent 150 object categories and 50 predicates of the VG dataset. We use 70% of the images for training and the remaining 30% for testing. We generated scene graphs using both VS3 Zhang et al. (2023) which used GLIP Li et al. (2022) as a building block for object and feature recognition, as well as the scene graph benchmark proposed by Tang et al. (2020). Unfortunately, scene graph detection quality is low, and error propagation from scene graph generation hampers the retrieval accuracy from 60% to around 19% (as shown in table 1). Therefore, we use Visual Genome provided scene graphs in our work to avoid error propagation from the scene graph to the next steps of the model and have a better analysis of the strengths and limitations of our retrieval and reasoning model.

references:
Table 2 shows accuracy for VQA task using KRVQA dataset.
NN+(K​Br​e​t𝐾subscript𝐵𝑟𝑒𝑡KB_{ret}+S​Gr​e​t𝑆subscript𝐺𝑟𝑒𝑡SG_{ret}) is our task-specific neural architecture while our retrieval model is used to retrieve the relevant part of the SG and KG (given the ground-truth scene graph and a relevant subgraph of the KG with preprocessing), as explained in section 3.2. LLM+(K​Br​e​t𝐾subscript𝐵𝑟𝑒𝑡KB_{ret}+S​Gr​e​t𝑆subscript𝐺𝑟𝑒𝑡SG_{ret}) is our model with LLM backbone, enriched with relevant KB and SG triplets extracted using the method introduced in section 3.1.

LLM model: The results for LLM-based model support the previous findings, though similar to the results in the previous section (Table 2), we can see that LLM models are moderately less accurate in comparison with the task-specific fine-tuned model (NN), which highlights the impact of a strong knowledge integration and reasoning module. Supporting the findings for NN model, the huge improvement resulting from adding visual knowledge retrieval demonstrates that a caption does not adequately represent the visual data, and we need an alternative approach to feed the visual data.

references: From results in Table 6, we can see that the proposed reasoning model is strong enough to find the final answer by combining the supporting facts, although even in the presence of ground-truth supporting facts/reasons, questions type 2, 3, and 5 are harder to answer using our NN model. Moreover, by comparing the accuracy using the retrieval model versus the upper limit of accuracy using ground truth triplets, our retrieval methods hurt more for question types 2,3, and 5. We conjecture that retrieving relevant facts is harder when the head entity is missing. As shown in Table 6, for our retrieval-based model, KB-related questions are harder than non-KB-related models, although our retrieval accuracy for both SG and KB is similar. Moreover, the NN model has similar accuracy for 1-hop and 2-hop questions.

Results show that question types 3 and 5 are harder for the LLM model even in the presence of ground-truth knowledge. Since for question types 3 and 5, the answer belongs to the second hop, it might make reasoning more complicated and prone to noise. Another interesting result is that almost for all one-hop questions LLM beats the NN model, though for 2-hop questions it performs worse than NN which confirms the weakness of LLM models in multi-hop reasoning.
In Table 6, we can see that the LLM models work better than their corresponding NN models for KB-related questions which confirms the partial existence of implicit knowledge in LLMs.

We analyzed the impact of each source of knowledge (visual vs external) for our VQA task in Table 6. Moreover, We reported the effect of injecting retrieved knowledge vs the ground-truth knowledge which indicates the oracle setting and upper-bound for our models.
The NN-None model only integrates question representation with image CLIP representation, while the LLM-None model does not use any knowledge in the prompts.
